drawing_instructions.thinking: I'm looking at the blank canvas and feeling quite melancholic. I want to start by drawing a wilting flower - something that symbolizes sadness and decay. I'll begin with a drooping stem in the center of the canvas, using a wiggle brush to create an unsteady, weak-looking line that curves downward. The wavering line will reflect the unstable, fragile emotional state.

I see the wilting stem on the canvas, which captures the beginning of my sad expression. To enhance this feeling of melancholy, I want to add a drooping, withered petal falling from where the flower would be. I'll use the light red color in a soft, crayon stroke to show the petal's gentle, lifeless descent. The petal will start near the top of the stem and curve downward, symbolizing loss and letting go.

The wilting stem and falling petal create a poignant scene. To amplify the feeling of loneliness and despair, I'll add some broken, scattered teardrops using the wiggle brush in a muted teal color. These wavering lines will descend parallel to the fallen petal, suggesting tears falling alongside it. The unsteady, wiggly nature of the brush perfectly captures the trembling quality of tears and emotional distress. I'll place them slightly to the right of the stem to balance the composition.

The canvas shows a wilting flower stem, a falling petal, and teardrops - all expressing deep sadness. To intensify this melancholic mood, I want to add another teardrop trail parallel to the existing one, creating a sense of continuous weeping. The wiggly lines perfectly capture the trembling nature of falling tears. This additional teardrop trail will be placed slightly to the right of the existing one, maintaining the downward flow and adding to the overall feeling of sorrow.

Looking at the drooping flower stem, fallen petal, and tear trails, I want to add one final teardrop trail to complete this trinity of tears. In many cultures, things that come in threes have special significance, and three streams of tears feels more emotionally impactful than two. I'll place this third wiggly line slightly to the right of the others, creating a rhythm of falling tears that mirrors the sadness flowing down the canvas. The repeated pattern emphasizes the continuous nature of grief.

The canvas shows a wilting flower with falling teardrops, expressing deep melancholy. To complete this emotional scene, I want to add one final stream of tears that's slightly longer and more pronounced than the others. This fourth teardrop trail will add to the rhythm of descending tears, symbolizing how sadness can feel endless. The wiggly line will start even higher on the canvas, suggesting tears falling from an unseen source of sorrow above.

Looking at the canvas with its wilting flower, fallen petal, and multiple streams of tears, I want to add one final teardrop trail that's shorter and more broken, suggesting the tears are beginning to run dry - but the sadness remains. This last trail will be placed slightly to the right of the others, completing the cascading pattern while also suggesting exhaustion from grief. The broken pattern of the wiggle brush will create a more fragmented line, symbolizing how even tears can fade while sadness lingers.

Looking at the canvas with its wilting flower, fallen petal, and streams of tears, I want to add one more element that deepens the sense of melancholy. I'll draw a final teardrop trail that's the longest of all, representing how sadness can feel endless and overwhelming. Using the same teal color with the wiggle brush, this trail will extend from the top to the very bottom of the canvas, completing the visual metaphor of endless tears. Its placement on the far right will create a sense of completion to our sad composition.

The canvas shows a poignant scene of a wilting flower with multiple streams of tears. To further emphasize this deep melancholy, I want to add another fallen petal - this one even more faded and lighter in color than the first, suggesting the complete loss of vitality. I'll use a very light shade of red with the crayon brush to create a gently curving stroke to the left of the original petal, making it appear as if it's floating downward in a resigned, lifeless manner. This additional petal will enhance the sense of decay and loss in the composition.

Looking at the melancholic scene with the wilting flower, fallen petals, and streams of tears, I feel we should add one more element that symbolizes complete surrender to sadness. I'll add another stream of tears, but this time with a deeper teal color, suggesting these tears are coming from an even deeper place of sorrow. I'll place it on the far right, making it slightly shorter and more trembling than the others, as if the strength to even cry is diminishing.

Looking at the evocative scene of wilting flower, fallen petals, and streams of tears, I feel compelled to add one final stream of tears that's more fragmented and broken than the others. This last teardrop trail will be shorter and more scattered, placed at the far right of our composition, symbolizing how tears eventually begin to fade even though the sadness remains. Using the Keppel color in a darker shade will suggest these are the deepest, most exhausted tears.

Looking at the sorrowful scene with its wilting flower, fallen petals, and multiple streams of tears, I want to add a small, broken heart shape in the top corner. Using the light red color with a crayon brush, I'll draw it fragmented and incomplete, as if it's breaking apart. This will be placed in the upper left area where the scene begins, suggesting the source of all these tears and wilting flowers is a broken heart. The placement will help balance the composition while adding to the narrative of deep sadness.

The canvas is filled with falling tears, wilting flowers, and broken hearts - a profound expression of sadness. To deepen this melancholic mood, I want to add one final element: a soft, fading cloud of sorrow at the top of the canvas, from which all these tears seem to originate. Using the Tea Rose color with a light, gentle spray pattern will create a misty, tearful source that hovers above the scene, suggesting that the sadness is all-encompassing and continues to rain down tears.

Looking at the deeply emotional scene with its streams of tears, wilting flowers, and misty sorrow cloud, I want to add one final element that embodies pure melancholy. I'll create a gently drooping willow-like form using the wiggle brush in a dark Keppel shade, placed at the far right edge of our composition. This will be like a weeping willow branch, its form naturally expressing sadness through its downward-flowing lines. The placement will provide a sense of closure to our emotional journey across the canvas, while the darker shade suggests the deepest depths of sorrow.

Looking at this deeply melancholic scene filled with tears and wilting elements, I want to add one more expressive detail that captures the feeling of complete emotional exhaustion. I'll draw a small pool of tears gathering at the bottom of the canvas, beneath some of the falling teardrops. Using the Sky Blue in a lighter shade will suggest these are tears that have fallen and collected, symbolizing how sadness can accumulate over time. The gentle, curved shape will mirror the drooping forms above it.
